conversation.content: [stiffly] Oh, you're still here—I didn't expect anyone to be working on the grounds today, especially not you after all these years.
[measured] Your mother kept me on retainer right until the end, though I suppose you wouldn't know that since you haven't been back in what, seven years?
[defensive] My concert schedule doesn't exactly allow for frequent visits, and Mother understood that my work required me to be in Vienna, London, places where real music happens.
Real music. [dry laugh]
The azaleas look different from how I remember them—Mother always insisted on pink ones along the north wall, but these are all white now.
[coolly] The pink ones died during the drought three summers ago while you were premiering that symphony in Berlin, so I replaced them with a hardier variety that actually survives neglect.
[bristling] Are you suggesting I neglected something by pursuing my career instead of, what, learning about soil pH and fertilizer schedules like some kind of suburban hobbyist?
I'm not suggesting anything about you—I'm just saying the white azaleas don't need someone checking on them every day, [pointedly], unlike your mother did.
[tightly] She had nurses, excellent care, the best money could buy, which my 'absent' career paid for, by the way. [exhales] Every monthly check cleared without fail.
[quietly bitter] Checks don't hold someone's hand during chemo or listen to them talk about their son's latest review in the Times that she'd memorized word for word.
You seem to have appointed yourself as some kind of moral authority here, but last I checked, you were hired to maintain plants, not pass judgment on family dynamics.

[sarcastically gentle] Of course, you're absolutely right—I'm just the help who happened to be here for every birthday, every holiday, every doctor's appointment when her famous son was too busy composing.
[voice rising] You think I wanted to miss those things? You think it was easy being three thousand miles away knowing she was sick but having contractual obligations I couldn't break?
The garden doesn't understand contractual obligations—it just knows that someone shows up or it dies. [pause] Your mother understood that better than most.
[defensively] Well, the garden survived, didn't it? Just like everything else here, maintained and preserved and paid for by the person you seem so eager to vilify. [bitter laugh]
It survived because I've been here every morning for thirty years, watching things grow and die and grow again while you wrote your important music.
[coldly] I'll be selling the property next month, so you might want to start looking for another family to burden with your disapproval and your perfectly maintained grudges.
Already have another job lined up. [flatly]
[caught off guard] Oh. Well then, I suppose we understand each other perfectly—you've been planning your exit just as carefully as you've been planning this little confrontation.

[turning to leave] Your mother's favorite roses are behind the greenhouse, the yellow ones she planted the day you got into Juilliard—I've kept them alive for her. [quietly] Do whatever you want with them.
